Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

Use the following to answer questions 1–3.

A water balloon is launched by a catapult into the air. The water balloon is launched from 4 feet above the ground, with an initial vertical velocity of 40 feet per second.

The function \(h(t)=-16t^2 + 40t + 4\) models the height of the water balloon over the ground, in feet, \(t\) seconds after launch.

  1. What is the height of the water balloon 1 second after launch?

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 8.1.1. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 28 feet. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Will the water balloon still be in the air 2 seconds after the launch?

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 8.1.1 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is yes. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Using the graph, estimate when the water balloon hit the ground.

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 8.1.1. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is approximately 2.6 seconds. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

Use the following to answer questions 4–5.

Suppose you want to frame a different picture that measures 12 inches by 9 inches. The frame is created from 46 square inches of framing material. The frame must be uniform in width, and all of the framing material must be used.

  1. Which of the following is true about the situation described?

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 8.1.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is the perimeter of the framed picture is greater than 42 inches. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. What is the total area of the framed picture?

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 8.1.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 154 square inches. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

Use the following to answer questions 6–8.

Suppose you want to frame a different picture that measures 9 inches by 8 inches. The frame is created from 38 square inches of framing material. The frame must be uniform in width, and all of the framing material must be used. Let \(x\) represent the thickness of the frame.

  1. What is the total area of the framed picture?

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 8.1.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is 110 square inches. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Write an equation to represent the relationship between the measurements of the picture and of the frame and the area of the framed picture.

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 8.1.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(4x^2 + 34x + 72 = 110\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. What does the solution to the equation in the previous question represent in this situation?

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 8.1.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is the thickness of the frame when all of the framing material is used. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

Use the following to answer questions 9–10.

A framed picture has a total area \(y\), in square inches. The thickness of the frame is represented by \(x\), in inches. The equation \(y = (2x + 5)(2x + 7)\) relates these two variables.

  1. What are the width and length of the picture without the frame?

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 8.1.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 5 inches and 7 inches. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Which of the following represents the area of the frame?

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 8.1.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(y - 35\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?
